importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the plane crash, which led to the deaths of all three people on board, including Grammy-winning songwriter Brett James.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The time frame during which the incident occurred, indicating the period when the flight took place and the sequence of events leading to the crash.

keyTakeAways: Brett James, a Grammy-winning songwriter known for his work with Taylor Swift, Bon Jovi, Keith Urban, and Kenny Chesney, died in a plane crash on September 18, 2025, in Franklin, North Carolina.
The National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) reported that the plane entered a 'tightening spiral' before crashing, with no mechanical issues found in the wreckage.
James had requested a visual approach to runway 7, which was approved by air traffic control, but failed to change to the common traffic advisory frequency, leading to a loss of communication.
James announced he was at 6,800 feet and would perform a 360-degree turn, but continued descending and eventually entered a spiral and crashed into a field.
All three individuals on board the Cirrus SR22T were killed in the crash.

namedEntities.name: Brett James
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The central figure in the incident — a celebrated music collaborator with major artists like Taylor Swift and Kenny Chesney — whose death is central to the story's public significance.

namedEntities.name: National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: U.S. federal agency responsible for investigating transportation accidents
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Provided the preliminary report on the crash, establishing the cause as a loss of communication and flight path deviation due to radio frequency mismanagement.

namedEntities.name: Cirrus SR22T
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Type of single-engine general aviation aircraft
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The specific model of plane involved in the crash, which was found to have no mechanical faults, indicating the incident was due to pilot or communication errors.

namedEntities.name: Franklin, North Carolina
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The geographic location where the plane crashed, approximately 270 miles southeast of Nashville, providing context for the incident's regional and logistical impact.

namedEntities.name: Runway 7
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Designation of the runway at the airport where the crash occurred
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The intended landing runway that James requested, which was approved, but which the plane missed during its descent and spiral.

namedEntities.name: Common Traffic Advisory Frequency (CTAF)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Radio frequency used by pilots to announce position when no tower is present
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The communication protocol James failed to follow, contributing to the loss of contact with air traffic control.

namedEntities.name: Taylor Swift
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: A major collaborator of Brett James, highlighting his influence in popular music and public profile.

namedEntities.name: Bon Jovi
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: One of the high-profile artists Brett James has worked with, contributing to his reputation in the music industry.

namedEntities.name: Keith Urban
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Another major collaborator, reinforcing James's status as a sought-after songwriter in the industry.

namedEntities.name: Kenny Chesney
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: A key artist associated with James’s success, particularly through the song 'Out Last Night'.

namedEntities.name: Carrie Underwood
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The artist whose debut album featured a song co-written by Brett James, marking his breakthrough in 2005.

namedEntities.name: Jesus, Take the Wheel
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Song co-written by Brett James and others
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: A pivotal song in Brett James’s career that launched his rise to prominence in the music industry.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The plane of Grammy-winning songwriter Brett James, a renowned collaborator with Taylor Swift, Bon Jovi, Keith Urban, and Kenny Chesney, crashed on September 18, 2025, in Franklin, North Carolina, after a failure to maintain proper radio communication with air traffic control. The National Transportation Safety Board reported that the aircraft, a Cirrus SR22T, entered a 'tightening spiral' during its descent following a miscommunication about radio frequency use, ultimately crashing into a field. No mechanical issues were found in the plane. The incident underscores a critical error in aviation protocol and raises awareness about the importance of adherence to communication standards in uncontrolled flight environments.
title: Songwriter Brett James’ plane enters 'tightening spiral' before crashing, NTSB says
